bug.author: terrybroad
bug.summary: 0.7.0 pip packages are not named properly (error: is not a supported wheel on this platform). [Will be fixed in next binary release]
bug.description:
My os is ubuntu 14.04 My python version is 2.7.6 Following the instructions for installing with pip I am getting this error:
$ sudo pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/gpu/tensorflow-0.7.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl tensorflow-0.7.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. Storing debug log for failure in /home/terence/.pip/pip.log
It works fine installing older releases of tensorflow with pip but not this one.

comments.comment: I had the same issues while trying to install tensor flow 0.70 GPU for python3 (pip3). For whatever reason, it was just the FILENAME which was wrong. It has to be in a special format to be legal. You can check yourself by following the instructions <denchmark-link:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28107123/cannot-install-numpy-from-wheel-format>here</denchmark-link> which tupels of tags are legal for your machine. In my case the command "sudo pip3 install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/gpu/tensorflow-0.7.0-py3-none-linux_x86_64.whl" produced the exact error message you got above. However, when i downloaded the file myself and renamed it to "tensorflow-0.7.0-cp34-none-linux_x86_64.whl", then executed the command again with changed filename, it worked =) Edit : OS = Ubuntu 15.10, Python = 3.4.3

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/terrybroad>@terrybroad</denchmark-link> do you have 64 bit ubuntu or 32? (run ) <denchmark-link:https://github.com/HellMood>@HellMood</denchmark-link> thanks for a workaround. I have to try it myself. We have intentionally used this name so that people with py35 don't have to rename it. It installs fine on 14.04 with py3 but we have not tried 15.10 yet.
I am seeing the same issue with Python 2.7.x on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (64 bit)
I can confirm this: I had to change py2 to cp27 in the filename after which it installed.
Exact same issue as <denchmark-link:https://github.com/terrybroad>@terrybroad</denchmark-link> on Ubuntu 14.04 (64 bit) with Python 2.7

Cheers <denchmark-link:https://github.com/HellMood>@HellMood</denchmark-link> and <denchmark-link:https://github.com/hannes-brt>@hannes-brt</denchmark-link> downloading it and changing to worked for me. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/jendap>@jendap</denchmark-link> I have 64 bit ubuntu installed.

I have the same issue, it did not solved by any of these solution. Here is the log. the same error message for py2 OS: ubuntu 14.04 64 bit. python2.7 <denchmark-code>HTTP error 404 while getting https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-0.7.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl Cleaning up... Exception: Traceback (most recent call last): File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 122, in main status = self.run(options, args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/commands/install.py", line 278, in run requirement_set.prepare_files(finder, force_root_egg_info=self.bundle, bundle=self.bundle) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 1198, in prepare_files do_download, File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 1376, in unpack_url self.session, File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/download.py", line 547, in unpack_http_url resp.raise_for_status() File "/usr/share/python-wheels/requests-2.2.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl/requests/models.py", line 773, in raise_for_status raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self) HTTPError: 404 Client Error: Not Found
</denchmark-code>
Same issue happening for me on Ubuntu x64 14.04 LTS and python 2.7
Same issue on Ubuntu 14.04 x64 Python 2.7 using commit <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/commit/3ff0f0d17b4eec946a2874da0cf896776c01a80a>3ff0f0d</denchmark-link>
Same issue on both CPU and GPU with Ubuntu 14.04 64x tensorflow-0.7.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. Storing debug log for failure in /home/artem/.pip/pip.log
Same issue on Ubuntu 14.04 x64 Python 2.7 and using GPU, downloading locally and renaming .whl file doesn't help, Tensorflow.6.0 worked fine. I did upgrade to Cuda7.5 and cudnn4 first.
(We will build the proper wheels for 0.7.1)
Hello vrv, I had a similar issue stated above with python 2.7.6 and cpu setup. But i ran the new wheel 0.7.1 and it worked for me.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> I can confirm that 0.7.1 works on Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64 with Python 2.7.6. Thanks!
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> I also can confirm that the new wheel works for my Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> I confirm that it works. Thanks.
Had the same issue.. this fixed it <denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> . Thanks!
Had the same issue and it is fixed with the new build, thanks <denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link>
The new 7.1 wheel installs properly and runs the mnist convolutional example just fine. Using Ubuntu 14.04 x64, Python 2.7 using GPU, Cuda7.5 and cudnn4.

Now it works ! I suggest you to create a link to <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/r0.7/tensorflow/g3doc/get_started/os_setup.md>https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/r0.7/tensorflow/g3doc/get_started/os_setup.md</denchmark-link>
in the installation section of the site. It could be easy for users with the same problem. Thanks
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> , the new 0.7.1 works for me on Ubuntu 14.04 x64. Both with Python 2.7 and 3.4 using GPU, Cuda7.5 and cudnn4.

Problem installing on Mac OSX 10.10 with Python 3.4: <denchmark-code>$ sudo pip3 install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/mac/tensorflow-0.7.1-cp35-none-any.whl Password: tensorflow-0.7.1-cp35-none-any.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. Storing debug log for failure in /Users/Sunil/.pip/pip.log </denchmark-code>
And here is the pip.log: <denchmark-code>/usr/local/bin/pip3 run on Wed Feb 24 23:29:18 2016 tensorflow-0.7.1-cp35-none-any.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. Exception information: Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 122, in main status = self.run(options, args) File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pip/commands/install.py", line 257, in run InstallRequirement.from_line(name, None)) File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.4/lib/python3.4/site-packages/pip/req.py", line 167, in from_line raise UnsupportedWheel("%s is not a supported wheel on this platform." % wheel.filename) pip.exceptions.UnsupportedWheel: tensorflow-0.7.1-cp35-none-any.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. </denchmark-code>
Was earlier able to install from mac/tensorflow-0.6.0-py3-none-any.whl
Downloading and renaming the file s.t. "cp35" -> "cp34" appears to work.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> The wheel 0.7.1 worked for me on Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64 with Python 2.7.6. Thanks!
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> The new wheel 0.7.1 fixed this problem for me also. I too am using Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64 with Python 2.7.6 Thanks for the fix.
Are you planning to fix this for Python 3.3 and 3.5 (which you claim to support)?

We do support python 3.3 and 3.5 in that TensorFlow does work with them when compiled from sources. However, since I suspect you mean provide pre-built pip wheels for 3.3 and 3.5 -- that is indeed what we would like to do, but we have not gotten around to yet.

However, since I suspect you mean provide pre-built pip wheels for 3.3 and 3.5 -- that is indeed what we would like to do, but we have not gotten around to yet.
Would be greatly appreciated if you could do this, I need to test a project which uses TensorFlow on Travis CI and don't want to have to build TensorFlow for each Python version every time I test.

I have Ubuntu 14.04 LTS 64bit and wanted to install tensorflow-0.7.1-cp34-none-linux_x86_64.whl and had the same error. This is what woked for me: <denchmark-code>sudo apt-get install python3-setuptools -y && sudo easy_install3 pip -y && sudo apt-get install python 3.5-dev -y && sudo apt-get install python3.4-dev -y sudo pip3 install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-0.7.1-cp34-none-linux_x86_64.whl </denchmark-code>
You have to call a tensorflow python script like so: <denchmark-code>#call it with python3.4 python3.4 tensorflow_demo.py </denchmark-code>
I have Ubuntu 14.04 LTS x86_64 with Python3.5 and it is giving me the same error for build 0.7.1, downloading and changing the filename is no help. What else can I try?
you need python 3.4. v3.5 is not yet supported. read 1 post above what did the trick for me.
I'm getting the same error for build 0.7.1 as well.
Closing, I think we fixed (some) of these issues in 0.8.0
I have the similar problem with Python 3.5 and it works with Python 3.4 ðŸ˜ƒ
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/vrv>@vrv</denchmark-link> I still get the same issue trying to install version 0.8.0 with python 2.7.11 on OS X 10.11.5

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/tobegit3hub>@tobegit3hub</denchmark-link> yes, that does not work. Python 3.5 will be part of net release. In the meanwhile you can try nightly build - <denchmark-link:http://ci.tensorflow.org/view/Nightly/job/nightly-python35-linux-cpu/>http://ci.tensorflow.org/view/Nightly/job/nightly-python35-linux-cpu/</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Jx-b>@Jx-b</denchmark-link> you are not alone. Using OS X 10.11.5 and having the same issue.
Thanks <denchmark-link:https://github.com/jendap>@jendap</denchmark-link> and all contributors

I had the same problem with 0.8.0 with both python2 and python3 installed. Didn't work even after renaming the wheel file. My problem was that 'pip' was pointing to the python3 installation instead of python2. Either using 'pip2' or properly linking 'pip' to the default python interpreter (python2 in my case) fixed the issue. To make sure the right pip version is used: pip --version pip 8.1.2 from /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages (python 2.7)
i can not install tensorflow on windows 8 64bits? i got this error is not a supported wheel on this platform

my python version is 2.7.6, the Linux version is Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS. When I installed tensorflow 0.7.1, i got the following error: /usr/bin/pip run on Mon Mar 13 09:30:39 2017 tensorflow-0.7.1-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. Exception information: Traceback (most recent call last): File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/basecommand.py", line 122, in main status = self.run(options, args) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/commands/install.py", line 257, in run InstallRequirement.from_line(name, None)) File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip/req.py", line 168, in from_line raise UnsupportedWheel("%s is not a supported wheel on this platform." % wheel.filename) UnsupportedWheel: tensorflow-0.7.1-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform. I do not know how to result the problem.
